titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Papers in the Sigmund Freud Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author: Prepared by Laura J. Kells with the assistance of Brian McGuire

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary

descriptivenote.p: Collection material in English and German

did.abstract: Psychoanalyst. Correspondence, writings, artwork, and other papers chiefly relating to Jacobson's psychiatric practice, psychoanalysis, the study and treatment of depression, and object relations theory.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Edith Jacobson, psychoanalyst, were donated to the Library of Congress by the Sigmund Freud Archives in 1980.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of Edith Jacobson were arranged and described in 1999. The finding aid was revised in 2008.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of Edith Jacobson is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Edith Jacobson are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Edith Jacobson Papers, Sigmund Freud Collection, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p:
The papers of Edith Jacobson (1897-1978) span the years 1922 to 1977 and relate primarily to her career as a psychoanalyst. They include
correspondence ,
writings , artwork, and a small amount of other professional and personal items. Much of the professional writing is in English, but most of the correspondence and poetry is in German.

Writings by Edith Jacobson and her colleagues in the field of psychoanalysis comprise the major portion of the collection. Topics include the study and treatment of depression and depressive conditions and object relations theory. One of Jacobson's early papers examines the psychological effects of imprisonment on female political prisoners and is based on her observations while being held as a prisoner by the Nazis before World War II. A brief description of her own experience as a prisoner can be found in a compilation of unpublished short stories and essays entitled "The American Oak Tree."

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in four series:

scopecontent.p: Letters received and a few copies of letters sent, primarily of a personal nature. Most in German.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent and chronologically therein.

scopecontent.p: Drafts and typescripts of books, papers, reviews, critiques, and poetry by Jacobson and papers and poetry written by others.

arrangement.p: Arranged by type of material, then alphabetically by name of author and chronologically therein.
